Louis-Dreyfus began her career in the early 1980s, appearing in various Off-Broadway productions and television shows, including the sketch comedy series "Fridays" and the sitcom "The First Comedian." Her breakthrough role came in 1982 when she was cast as Elaine Benes on the NBC sitcom "Seinfeld," a role that earned her three Emmy Awards for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Comedy Series.

After "Seinfeld" ended its nine-season run in 1998, Louis-Dreyfus went on to star in the critically acclaimed HBO comedy series "The New Adventures of Old Christine," for which she received multiple Emmy nominations. She also appeared in several films, including "Enough Said" (2013) and "Downhill" (2020).

In 2012, Louis-Dreyfus landed the lead role in the HBO sitcom "Veep," playing the fictional Vice President of the United States Selina Meyer. Her performance earned her a record-breaking six consecutive Emmy Awards for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series, as well as a Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Television Series – Comedy or Musical.

Throughout her career, Louis-Dreyfus has been recognized with numerous awards and accolades, including 11 Emmy Awards, a Golden Globe Award, and a Screen Actors Guild Award. She has also been inducted into the Television Hall of Fame and has a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

Louis-Dreyfus is also known for her philanthropic work, particularly in the area of women's health. In 2017, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and underwent treatment. She has since become an advocate for cancer awareness and research, using her platform to raise funds and support for various organizations.

Throughout her remarkable career, Julia Louis-Dreyfus has consistently demonstrated her impressive range, wit, and comedic timing, cementing her status as one of the most beloved and respected comedic actresses of all time.
